job_title: Sr Talent Acquisition Specialist in San Antonio, TX

cons: Hard work that is not for someone who doesn't want to take ownership and responsibility. Long hours but worth the effort.

job_title: Certified Advisor in San Antonio, TX

cons: Expectations, job duties, atmosphere, management

job_title: Faculty in San Antonio, TX

review_title: Decent Pay, Flexible Schedule, and Good People
job_title: Accounting Tutor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Schedules are flexible for students. You can cooperate with Professors. New connections are made everyday. Leadership is fair. Coworkers are friendly.
cons: Not enough hours at times. Outdated student scheduling system.

job_title: Academic Program Specialist in San Antonio, TX
pros: all the school holidays/PTO. My department is pretty flexible but other departments are so strict and hardly get a break from your desk. It really just depends which area you are in.
cons: The pay is not the best. There is favoritism. Lack of accountability. I feel that is everywhere.

job_title: Academic Lab Technician in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great entry level position. There’s plenty to learn and you’re able to gain experience. Once established everyday tasks are simple. Small department with great flexibility
cons: No upward movement within the job. Pay stays stagnant.

job_title: Administrative Services Specialist in San Antonio, TX
pros: -Lots of time off for holidays -Events/Free Food -Friendly Coworkers
cons: -Pay, depenending on what your job is. -Lack of training/support -Leadership -No career ladders

job_title: Student Ambassador in San Antonio, TX
pros: No matter who you are you will always be welcomed
cons: I wish they paid part-timers more

job_title: Peer Advisor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Flexible Simple Easy going Nice Lying
cons: Low pay Weak management No one knows what’s happening at a giving time

job_title: Accounting Clerk in San Antonio, TX
pros: Listens and values employee views and opinions, very welcoming and inclusive. Respectful to its employees. Great holiday time. Work life balance is great.
cons: Pay could be a little higher. Other than that, everything else about working there is excellent!

job_title: Member Staff in San Antonio, TX
pros: Decent state benefits and Paid Time Off.
cons: Slow moving, and no upward mobility opportunities. Does not hire from within, or in from its own community for administration openings. Leadership is consistently poor taking credit for the work of others. It does not follow its own set of values. Impossible to get a raise of any kind despite good performance. Low moral across the entire district.

job_title: Faculty in San Antonio, TX
pros: PTE programs, will hire faculty with a minimum qualification of an Associates Degree.
cons: Faculty pay could be higher

review_title: It’s okay if you are willing to be micromanaged

review_title: There is no panacea in academia
job_title: Professor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great students. Being student centered is valued. Sometimes the methods are questionable, but student success is always the goal.
cons: Like all academia- there is a political environment, budget issues, etc. We all wish we made more money.

job_title: Full Time Faculty
pros: >Academic freedom and autonomy is well defended > Faculty feed back is regularly sought after

review_title: No negotiating pay when taking new positions
job_title: Senior Coordinator in San Antonio, TX

job_title: Student Peer Mentor in San Antonio, TX

review_title: Two pay levels, make sure you sign up for the right one
job_title: Librarian in San Antonio, TX
pros: Colleagues are usually great at all 5 colleges
cons: Your pay will never advance. The current salary range for non-supervising librarian is 48-79k, but they will give you supervising responsibilities as 'other duties as required.' As for at least 20% more than the base because you never never advance. No one advances through the pay range. You stay where you are. No possibilities of any promotion.

job_title: Library Assistant II in San Antonio, TX
pros: The interviewing and hiring process was smooth and fairly quick. The pay was steady, consistent, and fair for the position. I enjoyed working with my department and communication was consistent. Many opportunities for learning and growth.
cons: There were not opportunities for a pay increase or promotion. I became frustrated with some of the politics, budgeting, and hierarchy of the district. I also felt that at a certain point, I deserved more pay than what I was receiving.

job_title: Sr Specialist in San Antonio, TX
pros: You collect lots of PTO, so that’s nice. Coworkers are awesome.
cons: The headline sums up how it is to work for Alamo colleges lately. Woke culture and lies about caring for your mental health abound. We did work from home rotations after coming back from covid, which was awesome and we still got our work done, but that was taken away. I guess the need for money beat the need for employee mental health. Health care isn’t wonderful. Staff is well overworked while being well underpaid.

job_title: Risk Management Specialist in San Antonio, TX
pros: Pay was decent, the campus i worked at was beautiful (Northwest Vista). Vacation hours were bountiful.
cons: Work culture was political and toxic. A lot of social games in order to “make it” at the company. All in all you are running into a big fish little pond type of culture here.

review_title: Fair and Balanced Place - Could use innovative processes

job_title: Analyst in San Antonio, TX
pros: - The students and professors were wonderful
cons:
- ACD is the definition of "rising to your level of incompetence". Unfortunately, the level seems to be very low. The HR department, in particular, is inept and filled with individuals who are either incapable or unwilling to perform their jobs with any degree of competence.
- Sr. leadership does not listen to employee ideas nor do they pay more than lip service to their "values"
- Pay is not merit-based, favoritism is rampant
- Competent employees leave for better opportunities quickly

review_title: Bruce Leslie is a TRANSFORMATIONAL LEADER, an idealist, a change agent which is why people are threatened by his style.
job_title: Director in San Antonio, TX
pros: The district organization promotes professional development and really, really cares about BUILDING CAPACITY FOR STUDENTS, especially students who are traditionally under-represented in higher education.  The district organization constantly seeks for best practices and performance excellence to be responsive to all stakeholders.
cons: Communication is a real issue here, but not because there is a purposeful intention not to be transparent.  The way the organization is structured, with five independently accredited colleges and one district office, there are no real lines of reporting or loyalty.  Shared governance is the organizational structure and it is highly complex which can lead to communication and implementation challenges.

job_title: Full Time Faculty in San Antonio, TX
pros: Like most college instruction positions the joy is in teaching and helping the students mature.
cons: This has to be the worst leadership for a college system. The District leadership is addicted to business class awards and has little to no respect for faculty or college staff. In every year I have been here there has been a flood of "chase the light" initiatives. The chancellor is constantly looking for new ideas to implement but rarely (if ever!) provides resources for them. He has taken tenure from the faculty; he has tripled the size of administration; he has demanded constant increases in average class sizes and the out-of-class demands on faculty is higher than any other place I have taught. The faculty are overworked and under-appreciated.

review_title: Good for students bad for employees
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: On the outside Alamo Colleges is doing many great things. The Chancellor seems like the best thing since sliced bread. The community loves this guy.
cons:
The Chancellor and most of the Presidents and Vice-Chancellors are in constant power struggles and put unrealistic weight on good employees.  This is not sustainable. Employees are not treated as human beings but rather widgets. This machine is bound to break as good employees are leaving in droves. 

There is no upward mobility unless you play the political game well.  The values and culture are from the lips out and nothing is really put to practice unless it proves a point and ignorant when inconvenient for leadership. 

The new Chancellor Dr. Flores gets a thumbs down.

review_title: Teaching here is fun, but the additional duties will wear you out
job_title: Instructor in San Antonio, TX
pros: High degree of flexibility in teaching courses, Department Chair and Dean are helpful for answering any questions you have, you can teach as many courses as your schedule allows, and you get paid for substitute teaching and certain Adjunct Teaching positions when needed.
cons: Many additional duties and membership on many committees detract from teaching time.  Hard to hire Adjunct Faculty to help out due to work hours or pay for classes.  Way too many reports that have to be typed up and submitted to the College Administration, sometimes requested by them at the last minute.

job_title: Instructor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Many great students!  It is wonderful to help students who have been somehow shortchanged in their education because of bad high schools or other life circumstances.  Truly is a place to turn around lives.
cons: Bureaucratic top-heavy nightmare of an organization.  Yet another educational institution obsessed with data at the expense of education.  The number of 'administrators' has been steadily growing, removing faculty from governance and advisement of students.  District is becoming a bit of a diploma mill, not concerned with even granting Majors on Associates degrees.  District Administration has a generic "high-school plus"   attitude,  not one of any passion about learning or the subjects taught.

review_title: Overall, a good place to work.
job_title: Associate Professor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Good group of people to work with, interesting work.  Opportunities for leadership roles.  Room to develop professionally.  Benefits and pay are good.
cons: Constant changes in policy, lots of jargon-laden trainings by paid consultants.  Politics can sometimes be challenging.  Adjunct professors are over utilized and under paid.  Increasingly, the focus is on a business model.  Expect to teach a high course load and be in the office from 8 to 5 every day.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: Autonomy of instruction, Department support, friendly and helpful faculty and staff, career flexibility.
cons: District leadership does not have student's benefit in mind.  Students need help with developmental instruction and support for learning.  Too much effort in trying to create student environment similar to Florida community colleges instead of focusing on San Antonio students' needs.

job_title: Special Projects Administrator in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great way to pay it forward and help others along the way. A great deal of staisfaction at the end of each day.
cons: There is not enough time and resources to help all that may need help. Lot's of additional resouces needed to help all students.

job_title: Network Administrative in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great people, facilities and staff.  The environment is great and makes you want to come to work.
cons: If I have to say anything, I guess parking could be a little better.  Maybe one day, they will get a paprking deck.

job_title: Instructor in Universal City, TX
pros: Student to faculty ratios are average and most of the students are motivated to learn.
cons: The current administration is very adversarial and will not work with faculty. There is no REAL shared governance. The District office is bloated with personnel and takes up about one-third of the budget.  Also, more than half of the board of trustees are anti-faculty.

job_title: Part-Time Lecturer in San Antonio, TX
pros: The staff were friendly and tech support was outstanding
cons: There was not a lot of training; I was teaching at risk students at a high school campus; it was difficult to get them enthused about learning

job_title: Instructor in San Antonio, TX

job_title: Instructor in San Antonio, TX
